text.headline: Early Evolutionary and Developmental Processes
text.text: Evolution of sexual dimorphism and gender differentiation, including the role of genes, hormones, and early sexual selection.

text.headline: Emergence of Primates
text.text: Early primates developed distinctive traits and social behaviours, enhancing visual acuity and grasping abilities, setting the stage for complex social interactions and gender roles (Ni et al., 2013).

text.headline: Early Primates Social Structures
text.text: Early primates developed rudimentary social structures with gender-specific roles centred around reproduction and resource acquisition, inferred from modern primate behaviours (Gingerich, 2006).

text.headline: Gender Segregation in Early Primates
text.text: Gender segregation emerged with differing roles in foraging and child-rearing, optimizing survival and reproductive success through specialization (Lovejoy, 1981).

text.headline: Sexual Selection Shaping Traits
text.text: Sexual selection drove the divergence of physical and behavioural traits between genders, enhancing mating success through body size and mating behaviours (Plavcan, 2002).

text.headline: Genetic Basis of Gender Traits
text.text: Genetic differences in hormone regulation and reproductive anatomy influenced gender-specific traits, impacting social behaviours and reproductive strategies (Del Giudice, 2009).

text.headline: Impact of Environmental Changes
text.text: Environmental changes prompted adaptations in social structures and reproductive strategies, reinforcing gender-specific roles (Janzen & Phillips, 2006).

text.headline: Tool Use, Bipedalism, and Gender-Specific Tasks
text.text: Tool use and bipedalism led to gender-specific tasks, with males focusing on hunting and tool-making and females on gathering and child care, enhancing social bonds and cooperation (Lovejoy, 1981).
